article:
'Allan S. M. Marat' CBE is a Papua New Guinean politician. He served as Minister
for Justice and Attorney General in Prime Minister Michael Somare's Cabinet from
August 2007 to May 2010. [http://www.postcourier.com.pg/pdfsfront/300807-PC-
frontpage.pdf "Somare's Cabinet"], Post Courier, 30 August
2007 [http://24hdanslepacifique.com/archives/actualites/?p=4045
"Rencontre des chefs de la police de Papouasie Nouvelle-GuinÃ©e"], Radio
Australia, 2 June 2009 [http://pidp.eastwestcenter.org/pireport/2009/May/05-15-
08.htm "PNG JUDICIARY UNDER STRESS"], The National, 14 May 2009 [http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/pays-zones-geo_833/papouasie-
nouvelle-guinee_578/presentation-papouasie-nouvelle-guinee_3547/composition-du-
gouvernement_3091.html "PrÃ©sentation de la Papouasie-Nouvelle-GuinÃ©e:
Composition du gouvernement"], French Ministry for Foreign Affairs, 29 August
2007 [http://www.abc.net.au/ra/programguide/stories/200812/s2439318.h-
tm "PNG Justice Minister receives death threat"], Radio Australia, 5 December
2008 In May 2010, he publicly stated that major mining projects in the
country brought little benefit to local communities, workers or businesses. He
also "questioned legislation affecting the Ombudsman Commission". Prime Minister
Somare consequently asked him to resign immediately, which he did. [http://24hdanslepacifique.com/breves-du-pacifique-
409 "DÃ©mission de lâAttorney General de Papouasie Nouvelle-GuinÃ©e"], ABC Radio
Australia, 10 May 2010 As a consequence of
his resignation, Marat informed the Prime Minister that his Melanesian Liberal
Party would "cut ties" with the government. He was replaced as Attorney General
and Justice Minister by Ano Pala.

He has also served previously as Deputy Prime
Minister [http://www.pngembassy.org/yearinreview_2.html Embassy of Papua New
Guinea to the Americas], 2003 and Acting Governor-
General. [http://www.gg.gov.au/governorgeneral/speech.php?id=455 "Speech:
ADDRESS BY HIS EXCELLENCY MAJOR GENERAL MICHAEL JEFFERY AC CVO MC GOVERNOR-
GENERAL OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA ON THE OCCASION OF DINNER HOSTED BY THE
HON DR ALLAN MARAT, ACTING GOVERNOR-GENERAL OF PAPUA NEW GUINEA"], 3 August
2008

In August 2011, Peter O'Neill became Prime Minister in the wake of a
parliamentary motion of no confidence in the government of Acting Prime Minister
Sam Abal (standing in for Somare while the latter was hospitalised for a heart
condition). O'Neill appointed Marat as his Minister for Justice, and Attorney
General. [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/world-leaders-1/world-
leaders-p/papua-new-guinea.html Cabinet of Papua New Guinea], CIA Factbook, 18
August 2011

In November, as the Supreme Court prepared to hear a case on the legitimacy of
the O'Neill government, Deputy Prime Minister Belden Namah ordered the
suspension of Chief Justice Sir Salamo Injia, as Injia was facing charges of
"breaching a contempt order, and mismanaging court finances". The government
said Injia's removal had nothing to do with the pending case on the government's
legitimacy. The Supreme Court responded by ordering Namah's arrest, and that of
Allan Marat. [http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=64345 "More
turns in PNG judicial saga with orders for arrest of senior cabinet ministers"],
Radio New Zealand International, 11 November 2011

He was, for a time, leader of the People's Progress Party, until he was ousted
from that position in October 2003. He is now a
member of the Melanesian Liberal
Party. [http://www.thenational.com.pg/083007/nation1.htm "Cabinet named"],
Isaac Nicolas, The National, 30 August 2007

He was the first Papua New Guinean to obtain a doctorate in law at the
University of Oxford. His thesis was on the "official recognition of customary
responses to homicide in Papua New Guinea". [http://books.google.fr/books?i-
d=MNr4iH0C4zYC&pg=PA66&lpg=PA66&dq=Allan+Marat&source=bl&ots=5dTV0JSYyy&sig=HoC-
g4qgcdvVsnKR82kLKE0qvZzM&hl=fr&ei=Nqc0SuGFK5qUjAf40_34CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct-
=result&resnum=10 Exchanging the past: a rainforest world of before and after],
Bruce M. Knauft, University of Chicago Press, 2002, ISBN 0-226-44635-2,
p.66

Marat was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the
2009 Birthday Honours for "service to law, the national government and the East
New Britain community". [http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2009/jun/13/queens-birthday-
honours-list-commonwealth "Queen's birthday honours list: Commonwealth"], The
Guardian, 13 June 2009
